text:
19th Road, north side, between Hazen Street (left) and Nineteenth Ave. (right), just west of an old pumping station. Behind this house is an old cemetery. This is stated to be one of the oldest houses in Newtown, standing in part of town, now Long Island City, on Bowery Bay. This place was erected about 1650 by Harck Siboutsen and left by his son Jacobus to his nephew Abram Lent in 1729. From the Lent family it passed to the Rapelye family. Isaac Rapelye owned and occupied it prior to 1852. See Annals of Newtown by J. Riker for more data.
? Date.

Arthur White.

19th Road, north side, east from Hazen Street to Nineteenth Avenues, showing in 4 views the Rapelje house. Bowery Bay Cemetery in the rear of the house contains markers of the 18th century for members of the Rapelje, Cornell, Riker, Luyster and other families. Chas. Rapelje (born 1786), purchased in 1830 the farm formerly owned by Daniel Riker. The estate of Chas. Rapelje, subsequent to his death in 1834, was given to his children David P., Isaac C., Catherine M., and Lavina P. Rapelje. The center room of this house was erected by Abraham Rycken who was the son of a first settler. He died in 1770. Daniel Riker who inherited it from his father Jacobus sold it in 1827 to Charles Rapelje. This house stands on the probable site of the Harek Sloutsen house. He settled here in 1650. In 1729 his son Jacobus willed the farm to his nephew Abraham Lent. Further history concerning these families and their properties may be found in the "Annals of Newtown", written by one Riker in 1852.

May 1929
View 2: 1922
View 2&3: March 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

19th Road, north side, east from Hazen Street, to Nineteenth Avenue, showing in a set of four views the Rapelje house. Abraham Rycken (born 1691; died 1770) erected the original house. The center room of the present house is said to be a part of the original structure. See other views for more data.

View 4:
